answers.answer: First thing to consider is that while being a vegetarian is great for some it isn't for others, so watch how you feel.  Being diabetic and going vegetarian can be tricky, because you have to avoid the simple carbs and make sure you get your good protein.  If I had diabetes and wanted to do this I'd do a lot of reading first and maybe see a holistic nutritionist to help me do it to make sure I didn't transition to a diet with too many carbs in it to replace the animal protein I had been eating.

I am a vegetarian myself so I have been studying this a bit. Vitamin B12, calcium and iron are good things to keep in mind as these things primarily comes from animalproducts and meat.

Actually, you're right about B12, though you can get that from spirulina and other fresh water algae, but calcium and iron sources are much better from plants than from animals as they are the most absorbed forms.  Iron is found in beets, parsley, nettles, dandelion greens, well, the list is very long.  The most well absorbed iron supplement is entirely plant based, Floradix.  You don't need a lot of iron, you need iron that's well absorbed.  As for calcium, again, green leafy vegetables, particularly the hard parts such as stems, are the most well absorbed form of calcium and also contain the proper balance of magnesium, which is usually lacking in animal foods.  Most Americans actually consume too much calcium because of the overselling of dairy and too little magnesium; both are essential for proper health and must be in proper electrical balance for both to work.  The only two nutrients hard to get in a well considered vegetarian diet are B12 and methionine.
